full_history.content: I'm designing a new multi-story hospital, which is obviously a critical facility. I need to understand the special structural integrity rules that apply to this type of high-risk building. Specifically, for a cast-in-place concrete frame, what are the fundamental requirements for tying the structure together to ensure stability, particularly concerning the connection of floors and beams to the columns?

A multi-story hospital in Virginia, classified as a critical facility [13VAC5-63-210], requires stringent structural integrity for its cast-in-place concrete frame, particularly in connecting floors and beams to columns.  The design must resist seismic and wind loads [3102.7] according to Chapter 16 of the Virginia Construction Code.

For cast-in-place concrete frames [1616.2.1], Section 4.10 of ACI 318 governs the design, requiring reinforcement or prestressing steel to pass through the column with specified tensile strength related to the vertical strength of the floor/roof connection. This strength is dependent on the presence and detailing of continuous reinforcement in the slabs [1616.2.1].

The connection of floors and beams to columns needs to ensure proper load transfer, as outlined in general structural design guidelines [3102.7]. Shop drawings for these connections, including mix designs and details, must be certified by a Virginia-licensed Professional Engineer [Fairfax County Guidelines].  Furthermore, the structure must adhere to a complete load path as prescribed by the code, transferring loads from their origin through the structure [Chapter 3 Building Planning, VARC2021P1].  Special inspections are required per Section 1705.3, adding another layer of scrutiny to ensure the structural integrity of the cast-in-place concrete frame in this critical facility.  Finally, local authorities should be notified for project review, although no fees are required from the VA [PG 18-3 Design and Construction Procedures].

Specifically regarding beam-to-column connections, ductile moment-resisting joints are crucial.  These joints must be reinforced for both shear and flexural demands, following the detailing requirements of ACI 318 and seismic provisions of the IBC.  [Seismic Design Requirements, H-18-8 and Seismic Design of Cast-in-Place Concrete Special Structural Walls].  Furthermore, beam end connections require a minimum nominal axial tensile strength related to the required vertical shear strength, with adjustments possible for specific slab and shear stud configurations [1616.2.2.2].

The provided context lacks diagrams or images.  While the text outlines crucial requirements, visual aids would enhance understanding of specific reinforcement detailing at these critical connections.  Therefore, consulting ACI 318 and relevant sections of the IBC in conjunction with this explanation is highly recommended.
